titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the William E. Irwin Photograph Collection
titlestmt.author: by Matthew Daniel Mason

did.unittitle: William E. Irwin Photographs collection.

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: Photographs of sites and individuals in Oklahoma Territory and Indian Territory, as well as Texas, New Mexico, Arizona, and other places in the American West, circa 1893-1935, chiefly created by William E. Irwin, as well as by his brothers, John Allison Irwin and Marvin Elmore Irwin.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from Michael Vinson on the Walter McClintock Memorial Fund, 2011.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The William E. Irwin Photograph Collection is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: William E. Irwin Photograph Collection. Yale Collection of Western Americana, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Collections are processed to a variety of levels, depending on the work necessary to make them usable, their perceived research value, the availability of staff, competing priorities, and whether or not further accruals are expected. The library attempts to provide a basic level of preservation and access for all collections, and does more extensive processing of higher priority collections as time and resources permit.

relatedmaterial.head: Associated Materials
relatedmaterial.p: William E. Irwin, Photographs of Kiowa and Comanche Indians (WA Photos 225). Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University.

bioghist.head: William E. Irwin (1871-1935)
bioghist.p: William Edward "Ed" Irwin (1871-1935) was a photographer active in Indian Territory, Texas, New Mexico, and Arizona, as well as other places in the American West, circa 1893-1935. He was born in Red Oak, Missouri, a son of William Pinkney "Pink" Irwin (1848-1924) and Mary Frances "Molly" Elmore Irwin (1849-1943). He had two brothers who also worked as photographers, John Allison Irwin (1869-1942), and Marvin Elmore Irwin (1881-1961), as well as two sisters, Lou Ida Irwin (1873-1873) and Minnie Pearl Irwin Bock Mitchell Sawyers (1878-1963). Between 1873 and 1878, the Irwin family moved from Missouri to their Buck Horn Ranch near Lometa in Lampasas County, Texas.

Around 1893, Ed Irwin learned photography from J. H. Hurl in Texas, and opened a photography studio in Chickasha, Indian Territory (later Oklahoma). Around 1895, he became partners with S. Jack Mankins (1871-1910), and they operated a photography studio, Irwin & Mankins, also known as the Blue Tent Gallery, in Chickasha until 1903, as well as studios in Duncan, Indian Territory, and Richmond, Texas. In 1903, Ed probably was a partner in the Irwin-Walk Studio in Lampasas, Texas.

In July 1900, Ed married Carrie Matilda "Tillie" Allen Irwin (1878-1922). In 1904, they relocated briefly to Silver City, New Mexico, where they likely continued to own a ranch, and then to Bisbee, Arizona, where Ed operated a studio with his brothers, John and Marvin, until 1922. Marvin also operated a photography studio in Douglas, Arizona, from 1912 to 1945.
In 1922, Ed moved his studio to Douglas, Arizona, probably collaborating with Marvin, and continued to photograph until his death.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Photographs of sites and individuals in Oklahoma Territory and Indian Territory, as well as Texas, New Mexico, Arizona, and other sites in the American West, circa 1893-1935, chiefly created by William E. Irwin, as well as by his brothers, John Allison Irwin and Marvin Elmore Irwin.

A significant portion of the collection documents American Indians, including Comanche Indians and Kiowa Indians, in the Oklahoma Territory and Indian Territory, circa 1893 to 1903. These images created by William E. Irwin and his partner S. Jack Mankins that include portraits of individuals, couples, and families, as well as views of settlements and structures. The collection also includes photographs of the territories and American Indians created by William J. Lenny and William L. Sawyers, circa 1889-1891.

Other substantial portions of the collection include landscape views of Texas, New Mexico, and Arizona, as well as hunting parties for deer and fowl in the states, circa 1893-1945. Many of the images include members of the Irwin family or property owned by them, such as the Buck Horn Ranch near Lometa, Texas, owned by William Pinkney "Pink" Irwin. Images of Arizona also include overviews of mining operations, especially in and around Bisbee.

A small portion of the collection documents activities in northern Mexico. These images include deer and puma hunting parties in the Sierra Madre Occidental mountains and Mexican-American Border region in 1907 and 1910. Groups of images relate to the Mexican Revolution, 1910-1913, including the aftermath of the Battle of Naco in April 1913, as well as portraits of Álvaro Obregón Salido and Venustiano Carranza de la Garza. Images of other states in the American West document trips to Alaska, California, Colorado, and Yellowstone National Park.
The collection also includes portraits of the extended Irwin family and friends, as well as a small group of ephemera that documents tax receipts for land in Texas.

The collection includes different photographic presentation methods of the same image, including unmounted and mounted photographic prints, as well as cabinet photographs and photographic postcards. Many discrete images in the collection share the same inscriptions in the negative or on their versos. Additionally, photographers frequently printed images of clouds in landscape views using separate negatives.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into twelve series: I. Alaska, circa 1900. II. Arizona, circa 1904-1945. III. California, 1927-1944. IV. Colorado, circa 1904-1935. V. Mexico, 1907-1913. VI. New Mexico, circa 1904-1935. VII. Oklahoma Territory and Indian Territory, circa 1893-1903. VIII. Portraits of American Indians, circa 1893-1903. IX. Texas, circa 1893-1940. X. Yellowstone National Park, circa 1895-1905. XI. Irwin Family, 1885-circa 1930. XII. Collected Photographs, circa 1889-1940.

did.unittitle: Alaska

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series I is organized into seven subseries: Anchorage, Chena River, Cordova, Dry Bay, Fairbanks, Seward, and Unidentified Location in Alaska

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series chiefly consists of landscape views of sites throughout Alaska, as well as sled dog teams, hunting parties, and cabins.

did.unittitle: Arizona

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series II is organized into thirty-four subseries: Bisbee, Black River, Canyon Lake, Cave Creek Canyon, Chiricahua Mountains, Clifton, Douglas, Fort Thomas, Gila River, Guadalupe Canyon, Kaibab National Forest, Lee's Ferry, Mission San José de Tumacácori, Mission San Xavier del Bac, Morenci, Mormon Flat Dam, Naco, Nogales, O.K. Ranch, Painted Desert, Patagonia, Payson, Ramsey Canyon, Rincon Mountains, Sacramento Hill Mine, Santa Catalina Mountains, Theodore Roosevelt Dam, Tombstone, Tucson, Wellton, Winkelman, Yuma, Unidentified Locations in Arizona (Film Rolls 16 and 24), and Unidentified Locations in Arizona

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series chiefly consists of landscape views of sites throughout Arizona, as well as images of mining operations, roads, and ranches. Many images depict members of the Irwin family, as well as a few informal portraits of Tohono O'odham Indians.

did.unittitle: Mexico

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series V is organized into four subseries: Naco, Sonora; Sierra Madre Occidental; Mexican-American Border Region; and Unidentified Locations in Mexico

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series chiefly consists of images related to a hunting party in the Sierra Madre Occidental mountains in November 1907, and the Mexican Revolution, 1910-1913.

scopecontent.p: Inscription on recto: "Naco burning during battle"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Inscription on recto: "Rebels carrying in supplies from the rear after the battle, Naco, Sonora. Sacks of sand on top of building used for breastworks during battle."

arrangement.head: Arrangement

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series chiefly consists of landscape views of sites throughout New Mexico, as well as views of ranches, highways, and mining operations.

Oklahoma Territory and Indian Territory

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series VIII is organized into fifteen subseries: Anadarko, Cache, Caddo County, Chickasha, Choctaw Nation, Davis, Duncan, Fort Reno, Fort Sill, Gotebo, Minco, Mountain View, Oakdale, Washita River, and Unidentified Locations in Indian Territory and Oklahoma Territory

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series chiefly consists of views of sites and scenes in the separate territories of Oklahoma Territory and Indian Territory, which later combined to become the state of Oklahoma. Images include American Indian settlements and structures, as well as views of American Indians at identified locations in the territories. Many images also document deer and fowl hunting parties in the territories.

Portraits of American Indians

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series VIII is organized into six subseries: Exterior Portraits of Identified Individuals, Exterior Portraits of Unidentified Individuals, Interior Portraits of Unidentified Individuals, Studio Portraits of Identified Individuals; Studio Portraits of Unidentified Individuals, and Studio Photographs of American Indian Artifacts

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series chiefly consists of portraits of American Indians, including exterior portraits, interior portraits, and studio portraits. It also includes studio photographs of American Indian artifacts.
Views of American Indians at identified locations in Indian Territory or Oklahoma Territory are in Series VII.

Texas

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series IX is organized into twenty-one subseries: Austin County, Brown County, Dallas, Davis Mountains, Donley County, Edwards County, El Paso County, Fort Bend County, Greer County, Hemphill County, Lampasas County, McCulloch County, Menard County, Mills County, Montague County, Robertson County, San Saba County, Texas Panhandle Region, Texas Panhandle Region, Waller County, and Unidentified Locations in Texas

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series chiefly consists of landscape views of sites throughout Texas, including ranches. Many images also document deer and fowl hunting parties.
Portraits of American Indians with identified locations in Indian Territory or Oklahoma Territory are in Series VII.

did.unittitle: Greer County

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: The Texas State Legislature Greer County created Greer County in February 1860 on land claimed by both Texas and the United States. In the case, United States v. State of Texas , 162 U.S. 1 (1896), the United States Supreme court held that the land belonged to the United States, and it became part of Oklahoma Territory.
